comments.text: The Mac GUI guidelines ask that the title of the menu remains highlighted until the action is done. But you switch back to the old menu before answering the dialog box (it's now behind your main window). I'm not sure what the guidelines say in such a case.
comments.author: jo.hermans@gmail.com
comments.creator: jo.hermans@gmail.com
comments.raw_text: The Mac GUI guidelines ask that the title of the menu remains highlighted until the action is done. But you switch back to the old menu before answering the dialog box (it's now behind your main window). I'm not sure what the guidelines say in such a case.

See also : request bug 682549, request bug 682550, request bug 682556, request bug 682557.

(In reply to Jo Hermans from comment #1)

> The Mac GUI guidelines ask that the title of the menu remains highlighted
> until the action is done.

Are you sure ? In both Safari and TextEdit, I choose some action via a menu, that brings a dialog, the action is not done yet, and the menu is no longer highlighted. Whether the dialog is a sheet or not. I find that logical, because in the dialog I may need a menu, like the Edit menu to paste or the Flag menu to enter characters. Furthermore, such a guideline would hinder the application menu (e.g. the Safari menu) - used to hide / show the application and her comrades - and the system-wide menus like the Apple menu and the handy ones at the right (AirPort, Sound…). But during the action I can anyway switch application thanks to the Dock and to Apple Tab. So such a guideline would be inconsistent, Mac OS X is deeply multi-applications.

Anyway, the action from the Window menu was : switching to the dialog. As soon as the dialog "Ouverture de FastIcns v3.1.dmg" became the foreground window, the action was done.

comments.raw_text:
As a former Mac developer starting in 1990, yes, I'm very sure. It was a very important part of the feedback from the Mac OS, even when you pressed cmd-C, you saw the "Edit" flash for 0.2 seconds. And you were supposed to flash the File menu when you were exiting the application (back when computers were still slow enough). Note that Windows never copied this behavior.

Unfortunately, most modern applications have forgotten about the rule, and since it was written for mostly modal dialogs, it has a bit of trouble fitting in a multithreaded environment (one thread could 'block' the UI for another one). And about the sheet - that's not really modal at all.

See for instance bug 109844, bug 507785.

See also the comment in bug 682549, which an explanation for what you see here.

comments.raw_text:
(In reply to Jo Hermans from comment #3)

Respect to your Mac OS background, Jo.
In the current Apple HIG guidelines, I have not found the rule you stated.
I remember that, during a modal action, all the menus were grey, except at least the Edit menu - because of its usefulness for the modal action.
Now, in Mac OS X, actions are much less modal.

My Safari flashes the File menu when I press Apple N.
